items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We do not expect to see similar impacts for tomorrow's high tides.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

This flood alert remains in force because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely tomorrow morning on 19/11/2022 between 01:30 AM and 03:30 AM due to large waves and spray. Areas most at risk include the area around the lifeboat station at Bridlington. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled, and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.   
We continue to monitor the situation.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Upper River Wey, especially in the Tilford, Bordon and Godalming areas, as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this evening (18/11/2022) and overnight into tomorrow (19/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mainly dry day, evening and night. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow afternoon, 19/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated this evening, 18/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: levels are falling at Semmington, Bathford and at Bradford on Avon, so the risk of flooding to low lying land remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford and the flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated on the morning of Saturday 19th November, or sooner if the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Mancetter river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Anker between Nuneaton and Tamworth the River Sence between Temple Mill and Ratcliffe Culey.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated this evening, 18/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne, especially in the Free Prae Road area, as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this evening (18/11/2022) and overnight into tomorrow (19/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mainly dry day, evening and night. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  -  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We will continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.

River levels have risen at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue overnight into tomorrow, 19/11/22 and over the next few days. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9:00, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022.  Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road.   
  We expect river levels to remain high until at least tomorrow afternoon.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wiske and tributaries to the River Swale

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, Winton Beck

items.message: River levels are forecast to rise on the Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, River Wiske, and Willow Beck due to a combination of rainfall on Thursday and high levels on the River Swale. Low lying land is expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Wiske around Kirby Wiske, Brompton Beck, Cod Beck, North Beck, Willow Beck, Sun Beck, and Winton Beck today, Friday 18/11/2022. Friday and Saturday are expected to be largely dry, although river levels will remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Gilling Beck, Skeeby Beck

items.message: There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

The flood alert for the River Rye catchment remains in force. River levels are remaining high on the River Rye catchment due to rainfall during Thursday, 17/11/2022, though levels are now falling steadily in most areas. Flooding of land is still possible on land around the River Rye and its tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck and Spittle Beck, including at Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. No further significant rainfall is forecast for Friday night or Saturday. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2022, or earlier if the situation changes.
This flood alert is no longer in force. River levels in the area have fallen below levels of concern. No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 24 hours.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Middle River Mersey catchment including areas near Bramhall, Stockport, Sale, Altrincham and Urmston

floodArea.county: Cheshire East, Manchester, Salford, Stockport, Tameside, Trafford, Warrington

items.message: River levels in the Middle River Mersey catchment have fallen and are returning to normal levels. The forecast indicates no further rainfall for today (18/11/2022) and tomorrow (19/11/2022). However, it is suggested that unsettled weather could return from Sunday (20/11/2022). We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels and will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  -  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We will continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.

We are removing this flood alert as river levels in the Lower River Calder catchment have fallen significantly. Please remain vigilant as standing water is likely to remain in fields and low-lying land for some time.  We are expecting further unsettled weather from Sunday onwards. Whilst rainfall totals are expected to be lower than those experienced on Friday, 17 November, rivers are likely to be responsive to any further spells of rain. We will continue to monitor the situation.

Levels in the Lower Rother catchment are now falling steadily following the high levels seen after yesterday’s persistent rainfall.  We anticipate that levels will continue to fall steadily through today and tomorrow, Saturday 19 November, although standing water may affect fields and other low lying areas for some time. Further unsettled weather is expected from Sunday onwards although at this stage rainfall amounts look more limited. However be aware that rivers will be more responsive to any further spells of rain.

We are continuing to monitor the situation closely and will reissue this flood alert if needed over the coming days.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington    
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated this evening, 18/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The flood alert for the River Seven catchment remains in force as river levels remain high around Normanby due to persistent heavy rainfall on Thursday, 17/11/2022 and overnight into Friday morning. Flooding remains possible on land around the River Seven and its tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck and Catter Beck, and to the East of Normanby. River levels around Sinnington and Normanby are falling but may rise again on Saturday afternoon. We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. The situation is improving, and no further flooding is expected in this area. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

The River Adur is still higher than normal but has fallen significantly from its peak and continues to slowly fall. Minor flood impacts affecting the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury, will ease Friday and Saturday. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Please keep flood protection products close by, in readiness for next week as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

The Eastern Yar is high but slowly falling. This month, over 200mm of rain has been recorded at Knighton, this is more than double the typical amount for November. 70mm of this rain fell in just 48 hours on the 16/11/2022. No further rain is expected until at least Sunday (20/11/2022). Water levels will continue to fall. At Alverstone, the level is decreasing by approximately 2-3cm per hour. At Sandown, the level is decreasing at approximately 1cm per hour. At Bembridge, channels will struggle to drain into the marsh while water levels remain high. This Flood Alert will remain in force while minor impacts to gardens, tracks and roads are still considered possible. We are operating Bembridge sluice to manage the water level at Brading marshes. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information. Avoid walking or driving through flood water. This Flood Alert will be updated by 14:00 on Saturday 19/11/2022.

items.description: River Bourne from Hadlow to East Peckham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Blackwater and The Cove Brook as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this evening (18/11/2022) and overnight into tomorrow (19/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mainly dry day, evening and night. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is still high between Fletching and Barcombe. Minor flood impacts will continue to affect isolated properties at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge, as well as in and near Barcombe Mills. Water will remain in fields and on rural roads. However, the River Ouse is now falling along its length. Very little rainfall is forecast for Friday and Saturday, which should allow the River Ouse to return to a nearer normal level by the weekend. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Some roads affected by flooding could still be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding including Barcombe Mills Road, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 19/11/2022.

items.description: The upper Stour and surrounding tributaries
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Teise and Lesser Teise area from Horsmonden to Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.message: The Cuckmere River is high in Alfriston but continues to slowly fall. Minor flooding will continue to affect North Street, Litlington Road, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers in Hellingly have fallen significantly from their peak and only minimal flood impacts are expected in Hellingly. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. The Cuckmere River in Alfriston will continue to fall, but river levels are unlikely to return nearer to normal until Sunday. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 19/11/2022.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes

items.message: River levels have fallen in places today, although they remain high between Leatherhead and Cobham, following the heavy rainfall over the last 48 hours. No further significant rainfall is forecast and we expect river levels to continue falling during this evening and overnight tonight. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 19th November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is still higher than normal but has fallen significantly from its peak and continues to slowly fall. Minor flood impacts affecting the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury, will ease Friday and Saturday. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Please keep flood protection products close by, in readiness for next week as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain across Kent earlier in the week. Levels in the Medway have peaked along the entire reach from Yalding to Maidstone and should begin to decline slowly overnight but, flooding of low lying land and towpaths is likely to persist into Saturday morning. No further rainfall is forecast until Sunday 20 November. This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday 19 November.

The River Ouse is still high but is slowly falling. Only minor flood impacts are expected in the Barcombe Mills area, which is covered by our Flood Alert that remains in force. Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane are likely to remain affected by some flood water until Saturday. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. The River Ouse will continue to fall. The river's fall will be slow and it will be higher than normal until next week. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please keep flood protection products close by, in readiness for next week as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

The Cuckmere River is still higher than normal, but has fallen significantly from its peak and continues to slowly fall. We still have a Flood Alert in force. Minor flood impacts affecting properties including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane, Alfriston will ease Friday and Saturday. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Please keep flood protection products close by, in readiness for next week as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

River levels are remaining high on the Middle Dorset Stour. Levels are currently falling at our Hammoon and Blandford river gauges but remain above the Alert Threshold. Areas most at risk include tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne. The Forecast is more settled over the next 24 hours with the expectation the levels will drop below the alert threshold tomorrow. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain across Kent and Surrey earlier in the week. Levels in the River Eden have peaked but remain high at the lower end of the catchment, particularly around Penshurst. Levels should continue to decline slowly overnight into Saturday 19 November. No further rainfall is forecast until Sunday 20 November. This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday 19 November.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. The situation is improving, and no further flooding is expected in this area. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

The Western Rother is high but slowly falling at Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. Flood water will continue to be close to properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth, with flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads and gardens in those locations. Between Liss and Midhurst, river levels have already fallen significantly from their peak, with only minimal flood impacts expected there. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. River levels will remain higher than normal in Fittleworth until Sunday. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Please keep flood protection products installed in Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. Please plan to avoid driving through roads prone to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 19/11/2022.

The River Arun is still higher than normal between Billingshurst and Pulborough, but continues to slowly fall. Minor flood impacts affecting properties at Pallingham Lock and the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst will ease Friday and Saturday. Between Horsham and Wanford river levels have already fallen significantly from their peak. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Please keep flood protection products close by, in readiness for next week as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

River levels remain high but steady on the River Roding at Abridge and Loughton. There is a risk of flooding to roads and low lying land due to high river levels throughout today, Friday 18 November.
The dry weather today has allowed the river level to slowly fall, however it is expected to remain high overnight and into tomorrow morning, Saturday 19 November. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and remain aware of the weather forecast. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Saturday 19 November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Whitwell, Wroxall, Langbridge, Alverstone on the Eastern Yar
items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar at Alverstone are now falling. The weather is now dry for the next 2 days. From Sunday onwards, more unsettled weather is expected, bringing further bands of rainfall. If this does affect the river, then we will issue further advice. We expect water levels to return to normal later today 18/11/2022. Any minor flood impacts should reduce by this evening. A Flood Alert will remain in force for the Eastern Yar while minor impacts remain possible. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The forecast for the next few days is for mostly dry weather.
We continue to monitor the situation, and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no significant rainfall for the next few days. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high, but has now peaked and will slowly fall through Friday. Flooding will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. The river should continue to fall Friday and Saturday, but will remain higher than normal until next week. In Barnham, river levels are already significantly lower than their peak and falling. Any minor flood impacts in Barnham should reduce. Another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause more flood risk next week. Some roads, including Shripney Lane may be impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We routinely clear grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 19/11/2022.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
The risk of flooding has now reduced. Following the heavy rainfall on Wednesday evening and Thursday morning, river levels are continuing to steadily fall. Scattered heavy showers will affect most areas today (18/11/22) and tomorrow. Catchments will remain sensitive to further rainfall. However, river levels are not forecast to overtop riverbanks. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, but there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the river forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary

items.message:
The risk of flooding has now reduced. Following the heavy rainfall on Wednesday evening and Thursday morning, river levels are continuing to steadily fall. Scattered heavy showers will affect most areas today (18/11/22) and tomorrow. Catchments will remain sensitive to further rainfall. However, river levels are not forecast to overtop riverbanks. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, but there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the river forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary

The River Arun remains high but has fallen from its peak in Pulborough. Flooding will continue to affect the A29 at Pulborough, with extensive water in fields and could affect properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. River levels could rise by a few centimetres in Pulborough Friday, but fall again Friday evening. Water will be close to the tops of the banks near Houghton Bridge, Amberley and may approach riverside properties, including near St Edmunds Cottage, Houghton. In Arundel, only minimal flood impacts are expected. Very little rain is forecast Friday and Saturday. However, the river is unlikely to return to a normal level until next week. Some roads, including the A29 at Pulborough, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please keep flood protection products installed in Pulborough, Amberley and Arundel, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 19/11/2022.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Stour, River Lodden, River Shreen

items.message: River levels are falling at our gauges in Gillingham and Sturminster Newton on the Upper Dorset Stour and Shreen Water but remain above the Flood Alert threshold. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Stour, Shreen Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton. More settled conditions are forecast over the next 24 hours with the expectation this alert will be removed by tomorrow. We continue to monitor the forecast and river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Showers are forecast for the remainder of the week so we will continue to monitor levels closely. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no further rainfall for today and tomorrow.
River levels will start to fall, but still remain quite high in some locations and a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: Rivers Stour and Iwerne at Stourpaine
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no further rainfall for today and tomorrow.
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall, but still remain quite high in some locations and a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.92 m and is stable.

The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.13m and is rising by approximately 11mm 

Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.

Pumping will begin at Episcopi pumping station when levels in the river allow.

Dry weather is forecast for today Thursday, 17/11/2022, with the risk of isolated showers.

The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to remain stable

We are closely monitoring the situation.   
  
This message will be updated at 12:00 on Friday, 18/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain across East Kent earlier in the week. Levels have peaked at all locations in Ashford and the wider area and will continue to decline slowly overnight. Flooding of fields, roads and car parks in the vicinity of the Stour and its tributaries may remain into the weekend.

The Hothfield and Aldington flood storage areas are retaining some water and are able to release this gradually. No further rainfall is forecast until Sunday 20 November. This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday 19 November.

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The forecast is for no further rainfall for today and tomorrow.
River levels are falling.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

The Western Rother is still very high in Fittleworth, but has fallen from its peak and will continue to slowly fall. Minor flood impacts affecting Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth and The B2138 Lower Street road will ease Friday and Saturday. We still have a Flood Alert in force to describe these minor impacts. Very little rainfall is forecast Friday and Saturday. However, another 10-30mm of rain Sunday and Monday could cause flood risk to return next week. Please keep flood protection products close by, in readiness for next week as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.message: River levels in the River Mersey Uplands have fallen and are returning to normal levels. The forecast indicates no further rainfall for today (18/11/2022) and tomorrow (19/11/2022). However, it is suggested that unsettled weather could return from Sunday (20/11/2022). We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels and will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: River levels continue to rise on the Lower Dorset Stour due to recent rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch. The forecast for the next 24 hours is for more settled conditions. River levels are rising at the Throop and Wimborne A31 gauge. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain across Kent earlier in the week. Levels have generally peaked at Tonbridge, East Peckham and at Yalding and should begin to decline slowly overnight but, flooding of low lying land and towpaths is likely to persist into the weekend. No further rainfall is forecast until Sunday 20 November. This message will be updated by 11am on Saturday 19 November.

items.description: Sandown, Brading and Bembridge on the Eastern Yar
items.message: Water levels in the Eastern Yar at Sandown and Bembridge are now falling. The weather is now dry for the next 2 days. From Sunday onwards, more unsettled weather is expected, bringing further bands of rainfall. If this does affect the river, then we will issue further advice. We expect water levels to return to normal Saturday night (19/11/2022). Any minor flood impacts should reduce over the next few days. A Flood Alert will remain in force for the Eastern Yar while minor impacts remain possible. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low lying land around Bonehurst Road area.  No further heavy rain is expected.
River levels are now falling, having peaked on Thursday but still pose a flood risk to roads, gardens and fields.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are ensuring that rivers are flowing freely and that any structures are working correctly.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Stilebridge
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain across Kent earlier in the week. Levels have generally peaked in all locations including Bethersden, Smarden and Headcorn. The peak is being registered at Stile Bridge now (10:00 on Friday, 18 November).  Levels will continue to fall steadily but flooding in fields and on roads in the vicinity of the river may remain into the weekend. This Flood Alert is likely to be removed on Saturday 19 November if not before.

items.description: Redhill Brook at Redhill and Salfords Stream at Salfords
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. The situation is improving, and no further flooding is expected in this area. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if required.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force following heavy rain across East Kent earlier in the week. Levels have generally peaked, or are peaking now, at all locations between Wye and Canterbury. The peak at Fordwich should be registered late morning today, Friday 18 November. Flooding in fields, gardens and on roads and car parks in the vicinity of the Stour may remain into the weekend. The internal flooding of property is not expected. This Flood Alert is likely to be maintained into Saturday 19 November.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River TIllingbourne at Shalford ,as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this evening (18/11/2022) and overnight into tomorrow (19/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mainly dry day, evening and night. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Lower River Loddon at Sindlesham Mill as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this evening (18/11/2022) and overnight into tomorrow (19/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mainly dry day, evening and night. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.43m and is falling by approximately 2 to 3 mm per hour. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 4.96 m and is stable. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m. Pumping will take place at Currymoor as river levels allow. The forecast is for the weather to be largely dry with a chance of isolated showers. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and this message will be updated by midday on Saturday, 19/11/22.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the Lower River Wey at Byfleet as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected this evening (18/11/2022) and overnight into tomorrow (19/11/2022). It is forecast to be a mainly dry day, evening and night. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England's webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes

Following the period of heavy rainfall yesterday across the River Witham catchment area, river levels remain high but are generally falling. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the rivers. This is expected to continue throughout the night of Friday 18th November and possibly into Saturday. Further rainfall forecast for Saturday morning is not expected to cause additional impacts. We are constantly monitoring river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday 19th November or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Esk from Briggswath to Ruswarp
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.

The River Arun remains high but has fallen from its peak in Pulborough. Flooding will continue to affect the A29 at Pulborough. Water will be extensive through fields and could affect gardens and properties on Lower Street and Swan Corner, Pulborough, near to Swan Bridge and Bridge Cottages, Greatham. River levels could rise by a few centimetres in Pulborough Friday, as a result of Friday morning's tide. However, river levels should fall again Friday evening. Very little rain is forecast Friday and Saturday, but the river will not return to a normal level until next week. Flooding of fields will continue until the weekend. Some roads, including the A29 at Pulborough, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Please keep flood protection products installed in Pulborough, if you have them. Our pumps in Pulborough are running to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 19/11/2022.

We are removing this flood alert as river levels in the Whiston Brook catchment have fallen significantly. Please remain vigilant as standing water is likely to remain in fields and low-lying land for some time.  We are expecting further unsettled weather from Sunday onwards. Whilst rainfall totals are expected to be lower than those experienced on Friday, 17 November, rivers are likely to be responsive to any further spells of rain. We will continue to monitor the situation.

Please remain vigilant as standing water is likely to remain in fields and low-lying land for some time.  We are expecting further unsettled weather from Sunday onwards. Whilst rainfall totals are expected to be lower than those experienced on Friday, 17 November, rivers are likely to be responsive to any further spells of rain. We will continue to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Frisby river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston. 
No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire

floodArea.county: Doncaster, East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, Wakefield

items.message:
Levels in the River Went catchment remain high following yesterday’s persistent rainfall. Levels at Wentbridge and Topham Ferry are now steadily falling and are expected to do so through tonight and into tomorrow, Saturday 19 November 2022. In the lower reaches of the catchment levels are likely to remain high for some time, until the River Don has fallen more significantly. Our operational staff are in the area checking our flood embankments and defences. 

Please remain vigilant as standing water is likely to remain in fields and low-lying land for some time. We are expecting further unsettled weather from Sunday onwards. Whilst rainfall totals are expected to be lower than those experienced on Thursday, 17 November 2022, rivers are likely to be responsive to any further spells of rain. We will continue to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 08:00 on 19/11/22.

This Flood Alert has been removed.    

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.   

The Rothbury flood gates are now open.  

We continue to monitor the situation as further rain is expected over the weekend.

We are removing this flood alert as river levels have fallen significantly. Please remain vigilant as standing water is likely to remain in fields and low-lying land for some time.  We are expecting further unsettled weather from Sunday onwards. Whilst rainfall totals are expected to be lower than those experienced on Thursday, 17 November, rivers are likely to be responsive to any further spells of rain. We will continue to monitor the situation.

Following the period of heavy rainfall yesterday in the Upper River Ancholme and River Rase catchment areas, both river levels remain high but are falling. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the rivers. This is expected to continue throughout the night of Friday 18th November. Our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. Although some rain is forecast for Saturday 19th November, we are not expecting it to cause additional impacts. We are constantly monitoring river levels and both flood storage areas have been operating. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday 19th November or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to prolonged rainfall in the Yorkshire Dales on Thursday 17/11/2022. Flooding is expected at riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and Naburn, in particular around Naburn Lock. River levels are forecast to rise further during Friday, and we have issued a flood warning for Naburn Lock. River levels in York are expected to peak late on Friday into Saturday, however will remain higher downstream of Naburn and within washlands. Friday and Saturday are expected to be largely dry days; however, levels will remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. Tidal levels are not currently of concern. From Sunday, further rainfall is expected, and river levels will remain high even if they fall slightly over the weekend. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 18/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding in the Harpers Brook and Willow Brook Catchment Area has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we will continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Ouse due to prolonged rainfall on Thursday, 17/11/2022. Flooding is expected at riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade from Friday morning on 18/11/2022. River levels are forecast to peak at approximately 3.3m late on Friday evening; we have issued some lower-level flood warnings as the river rises in the City of York. Friday evening and Saturday are expected to be largely dry; however, river levels will remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. Further rainfall is then expected on Sunday and Monday and levels will fluctuate. We are closing riverside flood gates in York and the Foss Barrier is in operation managing flows on the River Foss. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the River Nidd due to heavy rainfall on Thursday, 17/11/2022 and overnight into Friday morning. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Nidd, with low lying land expected to be most affected, in particular land around the lower River Nidd and its tributaries including Sand Beck, Sike Beck, Pool Beck and Great Gutter. Levels have peaked in most locations and are slowly falling. Saturday is expected to be largely dry. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area; and in Boroughbridge we have operated penstocks supported by routine pump activity. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This Flood Alert has been removed.    

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.   

We continue to monitor the situation as further rain is expected over the weekend.

Levels in the Middle Aire catchment are now falling steadily following the high levels seen after yesterday’s persistent rainfall. Levels are expected to continue to fall through today, Friday 18 November and tomorrow.  Please remain vigilant as standing water is likely to remain in fields and low-lying land for some time.  We are expecting further unsettled weather from Sunday onwards. Whilst rainfall totals are expected to be lower than those experienced yesterday, rivers are likely to be responsive to any further spells of rain. We will continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.    

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.   

We continue to monitor the situation as further rain is expected over the weekend.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: River Devon and Smite in Leicestershire and Nottinghamshire
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. We continue to monitor the situation.

Following the period of heavy rainfall yesterday across the Barlings Eau catchment area, river levels remain high but are falling. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the rivers. This is expected to continue throughout the night of Friday 18th November and into the weekend. Further rainfall forecast for Saturday morning is not expected to cause additional impacts. We are constantly monitoring river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00pm on Saturday 19th November or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Maun at Haughton, Milton and West Drayton
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold, however, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land.   
We continue to monitor the situation.

Levels in the Lower Don catchment remain very high following yesterday’s persistent rainfall. Levels are now slowly falling from Doncaster to Fishlake and are expected to continue to do so through tonight and into tomorrow, Saturday 19 September 2022. Norwood spillway is operating as designed, meaning water is spilling into Thorpe Marshes from Ea Beck, and this may mean Forstead Lane is inaccessible. Due to the levels still being very high in Stainforth area, the flood gate at Jubilee Bridge remains closed but we hope to be able to open it some time tomorrow.

Please remain vigilant as standing water is likely to remain in fields and low-lying land for some time. Further unsettled weather is expected from Sunday onwards although at this stage rainfall amounts look more limited, however, be aware that rivers will be more responsive to any further spells of rain.

We are continuing to monitor the situation closely and will update this message by 08:00 on 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

Following the period of heavy rainfall yesterday across the River Ancholme catchment area, river levels remain high but are falling. This has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the rivers. This is expected to continue throughout the night of Friday 18th November and into the weekend. Our Operations Teams are operating the South Ferriby Sluice to lower rivers between high tides. We are constantly monitoring river levels. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Saturday 19th November or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.description: River Ouse at York - St George's Field and Queen's Staith
items.message: River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to persistent rainfall on Thursday 17/11/2022. River levels are rising at the York Viking Recorder gauge. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse including the area around properties along Queen's Staith, on South Esplanade, Friars Terrace and Tower Place, St George's Field carpark and Rowntree Park. Flooding is expected in these riverside areas through York from Friday morning, 18/11/2022 and over the weekend. River levels in York are expected to peak late on Friday into Saturday below 3.5m. Friday and Saturday are expected to be largely dry days; however, levels will remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation and managing flows associated with the River Foss. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 18/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to persistent rainfall on Thursday 17/11/2022. River levels are rising at the York Viking Recorder gauge. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York from Lendall Bridge to Millennium Bridge. Flooding is expected in these riverside areas through York from Lendall Bridge to Millennium Bridge from Friday morning, 18/11/2022 and over the weekend. River levels in York are expected to peak late on Friday into Saturday below 3.5m. Friday and Saturday are expected to be largely dry days; however, levels will remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation and managing flows associated with the River Foss. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 18/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to persistent rainfall on Thursday 17/11/2022. River levels are rising at the York Viking Recorder gauge. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages. Flooding is expected in these riverside areas from Friday morning, 18/11/2022 and over the weekend. River levels in York are expected to peak late on Friday into Saturday, and at Naburn on Saturday or Sunday. Friday and Saturday are expected to be largely dry days; however, levels will remain high as the water makes its way down from the upper catchments. Further rainfall is expected on Sunday and Monday. We are closing riverside flood gates in York. The Foss Barrier is in operation. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00PM on 18/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Swale due to rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near Brough Beck and the River Swale, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Swale and tributaries from Catterick Bridge to the confluence with the River Ure on Friday 18/11/2022. Friday and Saturday are expected to be largely dry, although river levels will remain high. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.

items.description: River Ryton at Scrooby including Serlby
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  A Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding may still affect roads and low-lying land.  No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.   
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.

items.description: River Wreake for mills at Hoby, Thrussington and Ratcliffe
items.message: River levels remain high but are falling at the Frisby river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are Thrussington Mill, including Station Road, and isolated properties at Hoby. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are falling at the Frisby river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains but is reducing. Areas most at risk are Frisby on the Wreake, including Water Lane at Frisby, and Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until early tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Derwent due to prolonged rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Upper Derwent and Scarborough areas, including land around the Sea Cut at Scalby, Throxenby Beck, Old Malton, and Priorpot Beck in Norton from this morning, Friday 18/11/2022. No further significant rainfall is forecast; however, levels will remain high over the weekend. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Derwent due to prolonged rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Derwent, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Local roads and low-lying land around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington from this morning, Friday 18/11/2022. No further significant rainfall is forecast today or tomorrow, but levels will remain high over the weekend. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 19/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Clifton Hall river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is expected today Friday 18/11/22. Flooding is affecting the Harlaston to Edingale Road and low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Mease and Gilwiskaw Brook between Ashby and Croxall.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow, Saturday 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to fall but remain high at the Stapleford River gauge, and are slowly rising downstream following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 18/11/22. Flooding is affecting River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. 
Light rainfall is forecast for tomorrow, 19/11/22, but we do not expect this to have a significant impact on river levels. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22 or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thame and Chalgrove Brook as a result of the recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening 18/11/22, especially in the Thame Bridge area. 
Today and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry but further rainfall is currently forecast on Sunday and Monday. River levels in the River Thame have risen slowly through today but are starting to stabilise. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames for the Abingdon area
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Thames as a result of the recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening 18/11/22, especially in the Abingdon area. 
Today and tomorrow are forecast to be mainly dry but further rainfall is currently forecast on Sunday and Monday. We expect river levels to remain high overnight and through Saturday.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. 
 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 19/11/22, or as the situation changes.
